Then there's a history section detailing its origins, privatization, and key events like mergers and expansions. The finances section has revenue and income data from 2011 to 2022, showing growth. The main topics are the company's history, its structure and subsidiaries, financial performance, and recent developments. Key concepts include privatization, market position, subsidiaries, financial growth, and technological initiatives. I need to condense this into a concise summary. Let me make sure to mention the privatization, its role as a leading European telecom, subsidiaries, financials, and recent ventures like 5G and blockchain. Avoid specific dates and numbers unless crucial. Check for the main points: origin, growth, subsidiaries, financials, and current projects.

Deutsche Telekom AG, Germany's largest telecommunications company and the fifth-largest globally, originated from the privatization of the state-owned Deutsche Bundespost in 1995. It operates as a major provider of mobile and fixed-line services through subsidiaries like T-Mobile and manages a vast network of European and international operations, including significant stakes in regional telecom firms. The company has experienced steady financial growth, with revenues exceeding €114 billion in 2022, and remains active in emerging technologies such as 5G, blockchain, and Open RAN. Its strategic expansions, partnerships, and historical milestones highlight its role as a key player in shaping Europe's digital infrastructure.

[S1] Deutsche Telekom


# Deutsche Telekom



**Deutsche Telekom AG** (German pronunciation: [ˌdɔʏtʃə ˈteːləkɔm ʔaːˌɡeː] , lit. [S2] 'German Telecom'; often just **Telekom**, **DTAG** or **DT**; stylised as **·T·**) is a partially state-owned German telecommunications company headquartered in Bonn and the largest telecommunications provider in Europe by revenue. [S3] It was formed in 1995 when Deutsche Bundespost, a state monopoly at the time, was privatized. [S4] Since then, Deutsche Telekom has consistently featured among Fortune Magazine's top Global 500 companies by revenue, with its ranking as of 2023ᵘᵖᵈᵃᵗᵉ at number 79. [S5] In 2023, the company was ranked 41st in the Forbes Global 2000. [S6] The company operates several subsidiaries worldwide, including the mobile communications brand T-Mobile. [S7] It is the world's fifth-largest telecommunications company and biggest in Europe by revenue. [S8] As of April 2020ᵘᵖᵈᵃᵗᵉ, the German government held a direct 14.5% stake in company stock and another 17.4% through the government bank KfW. [S9] On 4th June 2024, the German government reduced its total shareholding to 27.8%. [S10] The company is a component of the EURO STOXX 50 stock market index. [S11] ## History

The Deutsche Bundespost was the German federal government postal administration created in 1947 as a successor to the Reichspost. [S12] It was also the major telephone company in West Germany. [S13] On 1 July 1989, as part of a post office reform, Deutsche Bundespost was split into three entities, one being Deutsche Telekom. [S14] On 1 January 1995, as part of another reform, Deutsche Bundespost Telekom became Deutsche Telekom AG, and was privatized in 1996. [S15] As such, it shares a common heritage with the other privatized Deutsche Bundespost companies, Deutsche Post (DHL) and Deutsche Postbank. [S16] Deutsche Telekom was the monopoly Internet service provider (ISP) for Germany until its privatization in 1995, and the dominant ISP thereafter. [S17] Until the early 21st century, Deutsche Telekom controlled almost all Internet access by individuals and small businesses in Germany, as they were one of the first German telecom units. [S18] On 6 December 2001, Deutsche Telekom became the first official partner of the 2006 FIFA World Cup. [S19] On 1 January 2005, Deutsche Telekom implemented a new company structure. [S20] The two organizational business units of T-Com and T-Online were merged into the Broadband/Fixed Network (BBFN) strategic business unit (T-Online merged with parent Deutsche Telekom in 2006). [S21] It provides around 40 million narrowband lines, over 9 million broadband lines, and has 14 million registered Internet customers. [S22] In 2008, the structure was changed again. [S23] T-Online was separated from Deutsche Telekom and merged with T-Com to form the new unit T-Home. [S24] In September 2010, Orange parent France Télécom and T-Mobile parent Deutsche Telekom merged their operations in the United Kingdom to create the largest mobile network in Britain, EE. [S25] In April 2010, T-Mobile was merged with T-Home to form Telekom Deutschland GmbH. [S26] This unit now handles all products and services aimed at private customers. [S27] In October 2012, Deutsche Telekom and Orange created a 50-50% joint venture named BuyIn for regrouping their procurement operations and benefiting from economies of scale. [S28] In April 2013, T-Mobile US and MetroPCS merged their operations in the United States. [S29] In February 2014, Deutsche Telekom acquired the remaining parts of its T-Mobile Czech Republic division for around €800 million. [S30] The size of the remaining stake was numbered at 40 percent. [S31] In December 2014, it was announced that Deutsche Telekom were in talks with BT Group on the acquisition of EE, and part of the deal was to provide Deutsche Telekom a 12% stake and a seat on the board in the BT Group upon completion. [S32] BT Group announced agreement in February 2015 to acquire EE for £12.5 billion and received regulatory approval from the Competition and Markets Authority on 15 January 2016. [S33] The transaction was completed on 29 January 2016.

[S1] Deutsche Telekom


# Deutsche Telekom



**Deutsche Telekom AG** (German pronunciation: [ˌdɔʏtʃə ˈteːləkɔm ʔaːˌɡeː] , lit. [S2] 'German Telecom'; often just **Telekom**, **DTAG** or **DT**; stylised as **·T·**) is a partially state-owned German telecommunications company headquartered in Bonn and the largest telecommunications provider in Europe by revenue. [S3] It was formed in 1995 when Deutsche Bundespost, a state monopoly at the time, was privatized. [S4] Since then, Deutsche Telekom has consistently featured among Fortune Magazine's top Global 500 companies by revenue, with its ranking as of 2023ᵘᵖᵈᵃᵗᵉ at number 79. [S5] In 2023, the company was ranked 41st in the Forbes Global 2000. [S6] The company operates several subsidiaries worldwide, including the mobile communications brand T-Mobile. [S7] It is the world's fifth-largest telecommunications company and biggest in Europe by revenue. [S8] As of April 2020ᵘᵖᵈᵃᵗᵉ, the German government held a direct 14.5% stake in company stock and another 17.4% through the government bank KfW. [S9] On 4th June 2024, the German government reduced its total shareholding to 27.8%. [S10] The company is a component of the EURO STOXX 50 stock market index. [S11] ## History

The Deutsche Bundespost was the German federal government postal administration created in 1947 as a successor to the Reichspost. [S12] It was also the major telephone company in West Germany. [S13] On 1 July 1989, as part of a post office reform, Deutsche Bundespost was split into three entities, one being Deutsche Telekom. [S14] On 1 January 1995, as part of another reform, Deutsche Bundespost Telekom became Deutsche Telekom AG, and was privatized in 1996. [S15] As such, it shares a common heritage with the other privatized Deutsche Bundespost companies, Deutsche Post (DHL) and Deutsche Postbank. [S16] Deutsche Telekom was the monopoly Internet service provider (ISP) for Germany until its privatization in 1995, and the dominant ISP thereafter. [S17] Until the early 21st century, Deutsche Telekom controlled almost all Internet access by individuals and small businesses in Germany, as they were one of the first German telecom units. [S18] On 6 December 2001, Deutsche Telekom became the first official partner of the 2006 FIFA World Cup. [S19] On 1 January 2005, Deutsche Telekom implemented a new company structure. [S20] The two organizational business units of T-Com and T-Online were merged into the Broadband/Fixed Network (BBFN) strategic business unit (T-Online merged with parent Deutsche Telekom in 2006). [S21] It provides around 40 million narrowband lines, over 9 million broadband lines, and has 14 million registered Internet customers. [S22] In 2008, the structure was changed again. [S23] T-Online was separated from Deutsche Telekom and merged with T-Com to form the new unit T-Home. [S24] In September 2010, Orange parent France Télécom and T-Mobile parent Deutsche Telekom merged their operations in the United Kingdom to create the largest mobile network in Britain, EE. [S25] In April 2010, T-Mobile was merged with T-Home to form Telekom Deutschland GmbH. [S26] This unit now handles all products and services aimed at private customers. [S27] In October 2012, Deutsche Telekom and Orange created a 50-50% joint venture named BuyIn for regrouping their procurement operations and benefiting from economies of scale. [S28] In April 2013, T-Mobile US and MetroPCS merged their operations in the United States. [S29] In February 2014, Deutsche Telekom acquired the remaining parts of its T-Mobile Czech Republic division for around €800 million. [S30] The size of the remaining stake was numbered at 40 percent. [S31] In December 2014, it was announced that Deutsche Telekom were in talks with BT Group on the acquisition of EE, and part of the deal was to provide Deutsche Telekom a 12% stake and a seat on the board in the BT Group upon completion. [S32] BT Group announced agreement in February 2015 to acquire EE for £12.5 billion and received regulatory approval from the Competition and Markets Authority on 15 January 2016. [S33] The transaction was completed on 29 January 2016.

qa_pairs.chunk:
[S1] In December 2014, it was announced that Deutsche Telekom were in talks with BT Group on the acquisition of EE, and part of the deal was to provide Deutsche Telekom a 12% stake and a seat on the board in the BT Group upon completion. [S2] BT Group announced agreement in February 2015 to acquire EE for £12.5 billion and received regulatory approval from the Competition and Markets Authority on 15 January 2016. [S3] The transaction was completed on 29 January 2016. [S4] In September 2015, Deutsche Telekom launched the "Puls tablet", a Tablet computer with Android version 5. [S5] In February 2016, at the Mobile World Congress, in Barcelona, Deutsche Telekom jointly launched the Telecom Infra Project (TIP) with Intel, Nokia, Facebook, Equinix, SK Telecom, and others, which builds on the Open Compute Project model to accelerate innovation in the telecom industry. [S6] Amid concerns over Chinese involvement in 5G wireless networks in Europe, Deutsche Telekom temporarily put all deals to buy 5G network equipment on hold in 2019, as it awaited the resolution of a debate in Germany over whether to ban Chinese vendor Huawei on security grounds. [S7] In February 2020, Deutsche Telekom joined a new partnership called HAPS Alliance to promote the use of high-altitude vehicles in the Earth's stratosphere with the goal of eliminating the digital divide. [S8] On April 1, 2020, Sprint completed the merger with T-Mobile US, making T-Mobile US the owner of Sprint and becoming its subsidiary until the Sprint brand is phased out. [S9] The merger also led SoftBank Group, the then-owner of Sprint, to hold up to 24% of New T-Mobile's shares while Deutsche Telekom holds up to 43% of its shares. [S10] The remaining 33% is since held by public shareholders. [S11] In September 2021, Deutsche Telekom sold T-Mobile Netherlands for €5.1 billion to the investment companies Apax Partners and Warburg Pincus. [S12] In September 2022, Deutsche Telekom is expanding its activities in the field of blockchain technology. [S13] DT’s subsidiary, Deutsche Telekom MMS provides the Ethereum Network with infrastructure in the form of validation nodes. [S14] In December 2023, Deutsche Telekom and Nokia with Fujitsu began deploying a multivendor Open Radio Access Network (Open RAN). [S15] The network is fully integrated into Deutsche Telekom's existing commercial network, including 5G AirScale compatible with Open RAN. [S16] ## Finances

For the fiscal year 2017, Deutsche Telekom reported earnings of €3.5 billion, with an annual revenue of €74.9 billion, an increase of 2.5% over the previous fiscal cycle. [S17] Deutsche Telekom's shares traded at over €14 per share, and its market capitalization was valued at US$68.4 billion in November 2018. [S18] The key trends for Deutsche Telekom are (as at the financial year ending December 31):

## Operations

Deutsche Telekom also holds substantial shares in other telecom companies, including Central European subsidiaries Slovak Telekom (Slovakia), Magyar Telekom (Hungary). [S19] Furthermore, Magyar Telekom holds majority shares in Makedonski Telekom (North Macedonia), and Hrvatski Telekom (Croatia) holds majority shares in Crnogorski Telekom (Montenegro).

[S1] In December 2014, it was announced that Deutsche Telekom were in talks with BT Group on the acquisition of EE, and part of the deal was to provide Deutsche Telekom a 12% stake and a seat on the board in the BT Group upon completion. [S2] BT Group announced agreement in February 2015 to acquire EE for £12.5 billion and received regulatory approval from the Competition and Markets Authority on 15 January 2016. [S3] The transaction was completed on 29 January 2016. [S4] In September 2015, Deutsche Telekom launched the "Puls tablet", a Tablet computer with Android version 5. [S5] In February 2016, at the Mobile World Congress, in Barcelona, Deutsche Telekom jointly launched the Telecom Infra Project (TIP) with Intel, Nokia, Facebook, Equinix, SK Telecom, and others, which builds on the Open Compute Project model to accelerate innovation in the telecom industry. [S6] Amid concerns over Chinese involvement in 5G wireless networks in Europe, Deutsche Telekom temporarily put all deals to buy 5G network equipment on hold in 2019, as it awaited the resolution of a debate in Germany over whether to ban Chinese vendor Huawei on security grounds. [S8] On April 1, 2020, Sprint completed the merger with T-Mobile US, making T-Mobile US the owner of Sprint and becoming its subsidiary until the Sprint brand is phased out. [S9] The merger also led SoftBank Group, the then-owner of Sprint, to hold up to 24% of New T-Mobile's shares while Deutsche Telekom holds up to 43% of its shares. [S10] The remaining 33% is since held by public shareholders. [S11] In September 2021, Deutsche Telekom sold T-Mobile Netherlands for €5.1 billion to the investment companies Apax Partners and Warburg Pincus. [S12] In September 2022, Deutsche Telekom is expanding its activities in the field of blockchain technology. [S13] DT’s subsidiary, Deutsche Telekom MMS provides the Ethereum Network with infrastructure in the form of validation nodes. [S14] In December 2023, Deutsche Telekom and Nokia with Fujitsu began deploying a multivendor Open Radio Access Network (Open RAN). [S15] The network is fully integrated into Deutsche Telekom's existing commercial network, including 5G AirScale compatible with Open RAN. [S16] ## Finances

### T-Systems

T-Systems sells worldwide products and services to medium to very large business customers. [S20] The focus is on the marketing of complex services and industry solutions. [S21] ### Deutsche Telekom Global Carrier

Deutsche Telekom Global Carrier is formerly known as Deutsche Telekom International Sales and Solutions. [S22] It is an international wholesale arm of Deutsche Telekom. [S23] The products include Voice Termination, Ethernet, IP-Transit, Mobile and Roaming as well as In-flight Internet Access for the aviation industry. [S24] It operates a Tier-1 network. [S25] ### European Aviation Network

Together with Inmarsat and Nokia, Deutsche Telekom develops a hybrid network for faster internet access on board the planes in Europe. [S26] It is a combination of data transmission via Inmarsat Satellite and Deutsche Telekom's LTE ground stations throughout the European continent.
